Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The standard Procure-to-Pay (P2P) process flow should typically follow this sequence: Create Purchase Requisition, Approve Requisition, Issue Purchase Order, Receive Goods, Vendor Invoice Received, Match Invoice to PO, Release Payment, Close Case. I used this standard flow as the benchmark to identify anomalies in the event log.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1001 follows the correct sequence of activities. Each step is in order: Create Requisition (CR), Approve Requisition (AR), Issue Purchase Order (IO), Receive Goods (RG), Vendor Invoice Received (VIR), Match Invoice to Purchase Order (MITPO), Release Payment (RP), and Close Case (CC). No anomalies were identified in this case, so it serves as a normal comparison point.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: In Case 1002, the activity 'Issue Purchase Order (IO)' occurs before 'Approve Requisition (AR)', which deviates from the standard flow where the requisition must be approved before the purchase order is issued.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Issuing the purchase order (PO) without prior approval allows unauthorized purchases and violates critical approval controls. The approval step (AR) happening on 2024-02-03, two days after the PO was issued (2024-02-01), confirms this anomaly.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: In Case 1003, the activity ‘Release Payment (RP)’ occurred on 2024-02-08 before ‘Vendor Invoice Received (VIR)’ on 2024-02-09 and ‘Match Invoice to PO (MITPO)’ on 2024-02-11. This deviates from the standard sequence where payment should occur only after invoice matching.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Releasing payment before receiving and matching the invoice can lead to overpayment or paying for goods not yet delivered. It violates financial controls by skipping critical invoice validation checks.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: In Case 1004, the activity 'Receive Goods (RG)' occurred on 2024-02-06 before 'Issue Purchase Order (IO)' on the same day. Goods should only be received after the purchase order has been issued.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Receiving goods prior to issuing the purchase order implies an unauthorized receipt of goods. This violates procurement controls as it skips necessary verification and authorization steps before receiving deliveries.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The identified anomalies suggest systemic issues in enforcing business process controls, such as missing real-time approval validation, failure to adhere to standardized sequencing rules, and premature release of payments without invoice validation.
